'''Salmar''' was a [[Maia]]<ref>{{S|Index}}, entry "Salmar"</ref> who entered [[Arda]] with [[Ulmo]]. He was the maker of the [[Ulumúri]], the great horns of Ulmo which produce the music of the sea.<ref>{{S|Days}}</ref>

== Etymology ==
The meaning of the name '''''Salmar''''' in [[Quenya]] is unclear. But, see [[Salmar#Early etymology|below]] for the meaning of his name in the early mythology.

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
'''Salmar''', also called '''Noldorin''', was a [[Valar|Vala]] in the early version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.

He entered the world with [[Ulmo]],<ref>{{LT1|III}}, p. 66</ref> and afterwards dwelt in [[Valmar]]. There he would often play music on his harp and lyre, sitting beneath [[Laurelin]], and [[Ómar|Ómar-Amillo]] his twin brother would sing as he played.<ref>{{LT1|III}}, p. 75</ref>

When the Valar decided to oust [[Melko]] from his fortress in [[Utumna]], he joined the rest of them in their attack.<ref>{{LT1|IV}}, p. 101</ref> Some time later when the [[Elves]] [[Awakening of the Elves|awoke]], he established a friendship with the [[Noldoli]], whom he loved.<ref>{{LT1|V}}, p. 126</ref>

After the [[Two Trees]] were destroyed, it was Salmar who first noticed that in [[Vána]]'s lamentation for them, there was still joy in her voice. When he pointed it out to them, the rest of the Valar gathered there heard the words: ''I-kal'antúlien'' (meaning "Light hath returned"), since Vána's tears caused a final shoot of Laurelin to spring forth.<ref>{{LT1|VIII}}, p. 184</ref>

Much later, after the [[Fall of Gondolin]], when the Valar finally decided to wage war on Melko in the [[Great Lands]] and free the enslaved [[Gnomes]], Salmar came with them. In the ensuing [[Battle of Tasarinan]], Salmar barely escaped;<ref>{{LT2|III}}, p. 154</ref> following his escape he went to the [[Iron Mountains (The Book of Lost Tales)|Iron Mountains]] looking for the Gnomes and to find their place of imprisonment.<ref>{{LT2|VI}}, p. 279</ref>

Nothing else is known about his future, except that he eventually returned to Valinor.<ref>{{LT2|VI}}, p. 278</ref><ref group="note">In an early, rejected entry in ''[[Qenyaqetsa]]'', it is said that Salmar, together with his brother [[Amillo]] and the Vala [[Erinti]] left Valinor to live in [[Tol Eressëa]], being the only three of the Valar that have done so.</ref><ref>{{PE|12}}, p. 36</ref><ref group="note">Salmar (Noldorin) was supposed to fight Melko along with [[Tulkas]] in the [[Battle of the Silent Pools]], in which Melko was captured - but his presence there was struck out.</ref><ref>{{LT2|IIIn}}, pp. 219-220</ref>

In one text though, it is said that he led the Gnomes back to [[Tol Eressëa]] after the war with Melko.<ref>{{PE|12}}, p. 67</ref>

=== Early etymology ===
''Salmar'' is a [[Qenya]] name, derived from ''salma'' ("lyre, small harp").<ref name=Pie/>

=== Other names ===
The [[Gnomish]] cognate of ''Salmar'' is '''''Salvor'''''.<ref name=Pie/>

Likewise, both '''''Noldorin''''' and '''''Lirillo''''' (another name by which he was known by) are also Qenya names: the first probably arising from his association with the [[Noldoli]];<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-1050955279.html|articlename=ᴱQ. ''Noldorin'' m.|website=Eldamo|accessed=23 March 2022}}</ref> the second meaning "Valu of the Song", containing either ''glîr'' ("a song, poem") or ''lir-'' ("sing") + masculine ending ''[[-illo]]''.<ref name=Pie/>

The Gnomish equivalent of ''Noldorin'' is '''''Goldriel''''',<ref group="note">''Goldriel'' was replaced by '''''Golthadriel''''', but subsequently both terms were struck out.</ref><ref>{{LT1|In}}, p. 22</ref> and that of ''Lirillo'' is '''''Glirlos'''''.<ref name=Pie>{{PE|14}}, p. 13</ref>

Another name for the character was '''''Avlon'''''.<ref>{{PE|11}}, p. 41</ref> It is in Gnomish, but its meaning is unclear.

== Inspiration ==
The characters of Salmar (Lirillo), Ómar (Amillo), and [[Erinti]] were likely inspired by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] himself, his brother [[Hilary Tolkien]], and Tolkien's wife [[Edith Bratt]], respectively.<ref>{{PE|14}}, "[[The Names of the Valar]]", ''note 23'', p. 15</ref>

For more information, see: ''[[Lirillion]]''.
